intro: Quercus vergens, commonly known as the Virginia oak, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown and thick, deeply furrowed bark. Its leaves are alternate, lobed, and turn vibrant shades of red and yellow in the fall. Quercus vergens produces acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species.
